G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from serious interference by the landlord (or those acting under the landlord’s control) with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from serious interference by the landlord (or those acting under the landlord’s control) with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes “quiet enjoyment” as a well-established landlord-tenant concept and states that every tenancy carries an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. It further defines this right as freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy, and ties liability to the landlord’s conduct, including acts or omissions whose natural and probable consequence is interference, which encompasses conduct by those under the landlord’s control. This aligns with the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, every residential lease contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting tenants from serious landlord-caused interferences with use and enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … [M]ore recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.” (385 Mass. at 102–03).

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, § 3, in that this is a civil action arising out of and relating to a residential rental premises located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Boston Housing Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the Premises are located in Dorchester, within Suffolk County, and the claims arise from Defendant’s conduct as landlord of that property.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, exercising ownership, control, and management of the Premises.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239, exercising ownership, control, and management of the Premises.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., requires that during the heating season (September 15 through June 15), the owner must provide and maintain a heating system in good working order and capable of maintaining every habitable room at a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at all other hours.

105 CMR 410.200.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., requires that during the heating season (September 15 through June 15), the owner must provide and maintain a heating system in good working order and capable of maintaining every habitable room at a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at all other hours.

105 CMR 410.201.proposition: The Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., requires that during the heating season (September 15 through June 15), the owner must provide and maintain a heating system in good working order and capable of maintaining every habitable room at a minimum temperature of 68°F between 7:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m. and 64°F at all other hours.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: To establish breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, a tenant must show that the landlord committed an act or omission that had the natural and probable effect of substantially interfering with the tenancy or rendering the premises unfit for the purposes of the lease.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reiterates the Simon/Cruz standard that liability under the covenant of quiet enjoyment arises when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interruption of the tenant’s rights, and notes prior cases where failure to repair known defects violated § 14. This aligns with the proposition that a tenant must show an act or omission by the landlord that naturally and probably results in substantial interference with the tenancy or renders the premises unfit. The court’s summary of its quiet-enjoyment jurisprudence directly supports that formulation.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘“natural and probable consequence” of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights.’ Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102, quoting Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942). … [I]n each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–77 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain a dwelling unit in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to repair defective conditions within the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that the tenant brought a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, based on severe code-related defects (heat, rodents, cockroaches, and other violations) that persisted after the landlord had notice, and the Housing Court judge found a breach of that covenant. While the Supreme Judicial Court does not elaborate on the legal standard for quiet enjoyment in this case—its analysis focuses on warranty-of-habitability damages—it expressly notes and leaves undisturbed the finding of breach, indicating that such conditions can constitute a breach of the covenant. The support is therefore implicit rather than developed in detail.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt:
The judge also awarded Wideman the equivalent of two months’ rent on her retaliation claim under G. L. c. 186, § 18. No issue is raised as to these damages on appeal. Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

… During her tenancy, she and her two sons endured continuing infestations of rodents and cockroaches. Heat in the apartment ranged from nonexistent (at worst) to insufficient (at best). Cruz Management had notice of these defects, as well as others… Most of the violations remained uncorrected through October, 1990, when Wideman finally vacated.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain a dwelling unit in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to repair defective conditions within the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.support_reasoning: The case does involve breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, but its basis is noise from a lounge operated on premises leased by the landlord, not failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code or to repair defective conditions in a dwelling unit. The court’s reasoning focuses on the landlord’s responsibility for objectionable noise it had the power to control, rather than sanitary code violations or failure to repair. Thus, it does not establish the specific proposition about sanitary code noncompliance and repair obligations.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain a dwelling unit in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to repair defective conditions within the landlord’s control, after notice, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case concerns breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment based on the landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures to curb criminal drug activity in common areas, not on failure to repair physical, code-violative conditions in the dwelling unit. The court explicitly cabins habitability/State Sanitary Code issues to the warranty of habitability and then holds that quiet enjoyment may be breached if the landlord fails to act against unlawful third-party activity it can control. It does not state or imply that failure to maintain the unit in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, after notice, is what constitutes the quiet enjoyment breach.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”}

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 200–03 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The obligation to provide adequate heat is a fundamental component of a habitable residence in Massachusetts, and the failure to maintain heat in accordance with the State Sanitary Code is a serious defect that can support a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly treats loss of heat as a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability, grounded in compliance with the State Sanitary Code, and characterizes a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation as not habitable. While the primary remedy discussed is rent abatement, the court ties the landlord’s duties to the State Sanitary Code’s requirements to supply adequate heat and hot water, making clear that adequate heat is a core component of habitability and that failure to provide it is a serious defect. Massachusetts precedent links such serious Sanitary Code violations to claims including breach of quiet enjoyment, so this case supports the proposition’s characterization of the seriousness of heat failures, even though quiet enjoyment is not the specific cause of action here.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable.”

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: The obligation to provide adequate heat is a fundamental component of a habitable residence in Massachusetts, and the failure to maintain heat in accordance with the State Sanitary Code is a serious defect that can support a finding of breach of quiet enjoyment.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with breach of the implied warranty of habitability and how to measure damages based on State Sanitary Code violations, but the excerpt contains no discussion of heat, heating requirements, or quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14. It instead focuses on valuation methods and whether minor versus major violations (windows, egress, electrical, basement issues) affect habitability and rent; it does not identify heat as a fundamental component of habitability or link lack of heat to breach of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it does not directly support the specific proposition claimed.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt: “While, following the Hemingway case, we did not attempt to furnish precise guidelines for the valuation of defective premises, we suggested that consideration be given to various factors including, but not limited to, the nature, duration and seriousness of the defects and whether they might endanger or impair the health, safety or well being of the occupants. McKenna, 3 Mass. App. Ct. at 172. … In all cases, however, the trial court is given broad discretion to determine whether defects constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 908–09 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts hold that a landlord’s repeated failure to correct building conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code, even after some repair efforts, may amount to an unreasonable and substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses State Sanitary Code violations only in the context of rent abatement and breach of the warranty of habitability; it does not address or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it analyze "quiet enjoyment" or unreasonable and substantial interference. The court notes that most conditions had minimal impact and that the landlord was fairly responsive, which cuts against the idea that repeated failure to correct code violations (even after some repairs) amounted to substantial interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, this case does not establish or affirm the quiet enjoyment principle stated in the proposition.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt: "Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs."

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199–201 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The conditions in Plaintiff’s Apartment violated the State Sanitary Code requirements regarding heat, constituting a material deprivation of services and facilities which the landlord is required to furnish.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurring/dissenting opinion and does not specifically discuss heat conditions in the plaintiff’s apartment or find that any particular State Sanitary Code heat requirement was violated. Justice Quirico instead discusses, at a high level, that violations of the State Sanitary Code can constitute breaches of the landlord’s obligations and affect rent liability, but he does not make a factual or legal determination that the conditions in this plaintiff’s apartment violated the heat provisions or amounted to a material deprivation of required services. Thus, the opinion provides general support for Code-based habitability obligations, but not for the specific heat-violation proposition stated.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… [which] fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions. It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units.”
